page.title: 01Heathylee
page.content: Heathylee is a large parish which is mostly above 300 metres O.D. It is drained by Oakenclough Brook and the River Manifold. The rocks are sandstones and shales of the Namurian Series. The climate is cold and wet because the land is so high. This results in a natural vegetation of heather and bilberry on the better drained soils and peat bog and cotton grass on the wetter areas; the river valleys had a tree-covering of willow and alder by the rivers and mixed woodland on the lower slopes of the hills. Now the land is mostly covered with pasture and meadow on the lower areas, though there is a small area of coniferous trees with a small number of deciduous trees interspersed. Most of the inhabitants are connected with farming, but there is one garage for repairs and fuel.
